elements.content: Self-assembly under hydrothermal conditions has been employed to synthesize several novel thorium-containing polymeric materials in the pyridinedicarboxylic acid (pydc) and pyrazinedicarboxylic acid (pzdc) systems. 2,3-, 2,4-, and 2,5-Pyridinedicarboxylic acid along with 2,3-, and 2,5-pyrazinedicarboxylic acid were utilized as organic linkers to produce thorium(IV) coordination polymers. Coordination of the thorium(IV) cations to the ligands in a bidentate fashion through a carboxylate group and either the pyridine or pyrazine ring to form a five-membered ring is a common structural theme throughout all of these compounds. Additionally, this choice of linkers allows for analysis of how the disposition of a second carboxylate group on an aromatic ring affects the overall structural topology. This aforementioned bidentate coordination is observed to vary as the arrangement between the carboxylate groups and N donor sites is optimized. In the pyrazine system, the frequency of this coordination is increased as the carboxylate groups are positioned on opposite sides of the ring while also providing the only form of metal-to-ligand coordination when 2,5-pyrazinedicarboxylic acid is the organic linker (compound 4). Presented are the syntheses, crystal structures, and a crystal-chemical discussion of these thorium-containing compounds.

elements.content: Novel thorium coordination polymers were synthesized hydrothermally in the Th-pydc and Th-pzdc system (pydc = pyridinedicarboxylic acid; pzdc = pyrazinedicarboxylic acid. A common structural theme is the coordination of the Th(IV) in a bidentate fashion through a carboxylate group and either the pyridine or pyrazine ring. Additionally, an analysis of the overall structural topology based upon the arrangement of carboxylate groups around the aromatic ring is presented.

Additionally, an analysis of the overall structural topology based upon the arrangement of carboxylate groups around the aromatic ring is presented.

elements.content: The crystal engineering of inorganic−organic hybrid materials has become an increasingly popular field of research over the past few decades owing to the potential synthesis of technologically important compounds with tailored topologies. As such, these hybrid materials have shown promise in a vast array of applications such as gas storage, magnetic materials, ion exchange, separations, optics, and catalysis. Many efforts have been geared toward the design of multidimensional hybrid architectures by taking advantage of the favored local geometry of the metal centers in addition to utilizing the functionalities and sterics of the organic components through which the metal centers are linked. While transition metal and lanthanide-based compounds have been explored rather extensively, the synthesis of actinide-based coordination polymers is receiving more attention. Additionally, it is essential to investigate the hydrothermal synthesis of actinide compounds as it bears relevance on our understanding of the nuclear fuel cycle and long-term stewardship of spent nuclear fuel.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The crystal engineering of inorganic-organic hybrid materials has become an increasingly popular field of research over the past few decades owing to the potential synthesis of technologically important compounds with tailored topologies. As such, these hybrid materials have shown promise in a vast array of applications such as gas storage, magnetic materials, ion exchange, separations, optics, and catalysis. Many efforts have been geared toward the design of multidimensional hybrid architectures by taking advantage of the favored local geometry of the metal centers in addition to utilizing the functionalities and sterics of the organic components through which the metal centers are linked. While transition metal and lanthanide-based compounds have been explored rather extensively, the synthesis of actinide-based coordination polymers is receiving more attention. Additionally, it is essential to investigate the hydrothermal synthesis of actinide compounds as it bears relevance on our understanding of the nuclear fuel cycle and long-term stewardship of spent nuclear fuel.

elements.content: Actinide elements such as thorium and uranium exhibit appealing topologies and coordination chemistry because of their propensity for achieving higher coordination numbers, features that are less common with transition metal elements. The synthesis of uranium(VI) compounds provides intriguing challenges due to the presence of the linear uranyl cation (UO2 2+). As such, additional coordination to the uranium metal center occurs through the equatorial plane to yield primary building units such as square-, pentagonal-, or hexagonal bipyramids and thus tends to induce one-dimensional (1D) chains and two-dimensional (2D) sheet structures. Thorium, on the other hand, typically displays spherical coordination thus avoiding such a “constraint”. Herein, we have extended our previous research in the synthesis of novel actinide compounds to include thorium(IV) materials in an effort to discover new structural topologies and themes.

As such, additional coordination to the uranium metal center occurs through the equatorial plane to yield primary building units such as square-, pentagonal-, or hexagonal bipyramids and thus tends to induce one-dimensional (1D) chains and two-dimensional (2D) sheet structures. Thorium, on the other hand, typically displays spherical coordination thus avoiding such a "constraint". Herein, we have extended our previous research in the synthesis of novel actinide compounds to include thorium(IV) materials in an effort to discover new structural topologies and themes.

elements.content: We have chosen 2,3-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (C7H5NO4, 2,3-pydc), 2,4-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (C7H5NO4, 2,4-pydc), and 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (C7H5NO4, 2,5-pydc) as the organic linkers (Scheme ) for this investigation. This series of related species will allow us to investigate systematically the effect of the disposition of a second carboxylic group around an aromatic ring on the topology of the resulting Th(IV) coordination polymers. 2,3-Pyrazinedicarboxylic acid (C6H4N2O4, 2,3-pzdc) and 2,5-pyrazinedicarboxylic acid (C6H4N2O4, 2,5-pzdc) (Scheme ) were additionally chosen to explore the influence of an additional nitrogen donor within the aromatic ring. Each ligand contains two distinct coordination modes involving the carboxylic groups and either the pyridine or pyrazine ring and thus creates multiple possible binding sites to promote higher dimensional compounds. These linkers have also seen success in heterometallic systems where distinctions based on binding site preferences is exploited. Indeed, many transition-metal based and lanthanide-based coordination polymers have been synthesized utilizing these linkers and have demonstrated properties in areas such as magnetism, photoluminescence, adsorption, and nonlinear optics. In contrast, there have been few reported actinide-based compounds utilizing the pyridinedicarboxylic and pyrazinedicarboxylic acids. Reported herein however are the syntheses and crystal structure descriptions of three thorium-pydc and two thorium-pzdc coordination polymers synthesized under hydrothermal conditions.

Experimental Procedures

 CAUTION: Standard precautions for handling the radioactive substance thorium(IV) nitrate tetrahydrate, Th(NO3)4⋅4H2O, should be followed. 

Thorium(IV) nitrate tetrahydrate [Th(NO3)4⋅4H2O] was obtained from Strem Chemicals. 2,3-Pyridinedicarboxylic (C7H3NO4), 2,4-pyridinedicarboxylic (C7H3NO4), 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic (C7H3NO4), 2,3-pyrazinedicarboxylic (C6H2N2O4), and 2,5-pyrazinedicarboxylic acid (C6H2N2O4) were purchased from Aldrich Chemicals, Inc. All reagents were used as received without further purification.

elements.content: All of the reactants, in their appropriate molar ratios, were dissolved in distilled water and placed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr bomb and heated. Upon completion of the reaction, the Parr bombs were allowed to cool to room temperature. The mother liquor was decanted, and the remaining crystals were subsequently washed with both distilled water and ethanol and then allowed to dry in air at room temperature. The molar ratios of the reactants and the reaction conditions along with the percent yields and the initial and final pH of the reactions for compounds 1−5 are summarized in Table . Elemental analyses were conducted by Galbraith Laboratories, Inc., Knoxville, TN.

Representative single crystals of 1−5 were extracted and mounted on glass fibers with epoxy. The crystal structures were determined via single crystal X-ray diffraction, and the crystallographic data are summarized in Table . Intensity data were collected on a Bruker SMART diffractometer equipped with an APEX II CCD detector. Data processing was performed using SAINT, and the structures were solved using direct methods. Refinements were carried out using SHELXL-97 within the WINGX software suite. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and all hydrogen atoms were either located in difference Fourier maps or placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically, with the exception of hydrogen atoms on the unbound water molecules which could not be located.

All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and all hydrogen atoms were either located in difference Fourier maps or placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically, with the exception of hydrogen atoms on the unbound water molecules which could not be located.

The crystal structure of compound 1 (Figure ) consists of a thorium(IV) cation bound to five 2,3-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (2,3-pydc) units. Two 2,3-pydc units are bound to the thorium metal centers in a bidentate fashion through the pyridine ring at an average distance of 2.698 Å along with a carboxylate oxygen atom at a distance of 2.355 Å resulting in an average O−Th−N angle of 61.85°. The remaining three 2,3-pydc units are bound to the metal center through carboxylate oxygen atoms, O5, O6, and O7, at distances of 2.359(11), 2.340(11), and 2.440(12) Å, respectively. Two water molecules are further bound at distances of 2.572(13) and 2.485(11) Å, respectively, to complete the 9-coordinate local geometry of the Th(IV). Viewing down the [010] direction reveals that the Th(IV) metal centers are connected through a bridging carboxylate group, O5 and O7, along the x-direction (Figure ). Within the yz-plane, a single 2,3-pydc connects two thorium centers to form the overall three-dimensional (3D) structure (Figure ). Furthermore, there are two water molecules, Ow1 and Ow2, residing within the pore spaces as can been observed in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of Th(C7H3NO4)2(H2O)2⋅2H2O, Compound 1 

The crystal structure of compound 1 (Figure ) consists of a thorium(IV) cation bound to five 2,3-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (2,3-pydc) units. Two 2,3-pydc units are bound to the thorium metal centers in a bidentate fashion through the pyridine ring at an average distance of 2.698 Å along with a carboxylate oxygen atom at a distance of 2.355 Å resulting in an average O-Th-N angle of 61.85°. The remaining three 2,3-pydc units are bound to the metal center through carboxylate oxygen atoms, O5, O6, and O7, at distances of 2.359(11), 2.340(11), and 2.440(12) Å, respectively. Two water molecules are further bound at distances of 2.572(13) and 2.485(11) Å, respectively, to complete the 9-coordinate local geometry of the Th(IV). Viewing down the [010] direction reveals that the Th(IV) metal centers are connected through a bridging carboxylate group, O5 and O7, along the x-direction (Figure ). Within the yz-plane, a single 2,3-pydc connects two thorium centers to form the overall three-dimensional (3D) structure (Figure ). Furthermore, there are two water molecules, Ow1 and Ow2, residing within the pore spaces as can been observed in Figure .

elements.content: The crystal structure of compound 2 (Figure ) has the Th(IV) cation bound to six 2,4-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (2,4-pydc) units and a water molecule to form the overall 9-coordinate local geometry of the metal center. Four 2,4-pydc units are bound to the thorium metal center through a single carboxylate oxygen atom at an average distance of 2.354 Å. The remaining two 2,4-pydc units are bound to the thorium in a bidentate fashion, similar to the one seen in compound 1, through a carboxylate oxygen atom at an average distance of 2.431 Å and through the pyridine ring at an average distance of 2.763 Å to form a O−Th−N angle of 61.0°. Finally, one water molecule is bound at a distance of 2.548(6) Å to complete the 9-coordination of the thorium(IV). Viewing down the [100] direction reveals that the thorium metal centers are linked via a carboxylate group, O2 and O3, from one of the 2,4-pydc linkages (Figure ). Additionally, we can observe this same linking of the thorium(IV) through O6 and O8 from another carboxylate group to complete the overall 3D structure (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of Th(C7H3NO4)2(H2O), Compound 2 

The crystal structure of compound 2 (Figure ) has the Th(IV) cation bound to six 2,4-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (2,4-pydc) units and a water molecule to form the overall 9-coordinate local geometry of the metal center. Four 2,4-pydc units are bound to the thorium metal center through a single carboxylate oxygen atom at an average distance of 2.354 Å. The remaining two 2,4-pydc units are bound to the thorium in a bidentate fashion, similar to the one seen in compound 1, through a carboxylate oxygen atom at an average distance of 2.431 Å and through the pyridine ring at an average distance of 2.763 Å to form a O-Th-N angle of 61.0°. Finally, one water molecule is bound at a distance of 2.548(6) Å to complete the 9-coordination of the thorium(IV). Viewing down the [100] direction reveals that the thorium metal centers are linked via a carboxylate group, O2 and O3, from one of the 2,4-pydc linkages (Figure ). Additionally, we can observe this same linking of the thorium(IV) through O6 and O8 from another carboxylate group to complete the overall 3D structure (Figure ).

elements.content: The crystal structure of compound 3 (Figure ) consists of a thorium(IV) cation bound to four distinct 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (2,5-pydc) units. Along the z-direction, each thorium metal center is bound to two 2,5-pydc units via a bidentate fashion through the nitrogen of the pyridine ring and a carboxylate oxygen atom at average distances of 2.721 and 2.436 Å. The resulting average O−Th−N angle of 60.56° is comparable to those seen in compounds 1 and 2. The second carboxylic group associated with these two linkers remains protonated and does not participate in further coordination. Each Th(IV) is also bound to three water molecules at distances of 2.446(4), 2.522(3), and 2.642(4) Å, respectively, to form [Th(C7H3NO4)2(H2O)3] monomers. Completing the 10-coordinate local geometry, two symmetry equivalent 2,5-pydc units tether these monomers into 1D chains. One mode of connectivity is through a carboxylate oxygen atom, O2, at a distance of 2.447(3) Å, while the second means of binding is in a bidentate fashion through N1 of the pyridine ring at a distance of 2.647(4) Å and a carboxylate oxygen atom, O9, at a distance of 2.418(3) Å, respectively. The packing of the chains is realized along [100] (Figure ). Moreover, there are two water molecules residing between the chains.

elements.content: The synthesis of novel thorium(IV) coordination polymers under hydrothermal conditions has been demonstrated utilizing a series of multifunctional ligands. We previously described a uranium(VI)-3,5-pyrazoledicarboxylate material, which contained a bidentate binding mode between the U(VI) metal centers to the linker through both the pyrazole ring along with a carboxylate group to form a five-membered ring (Scheme ). A search of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD; Version 5.28) using Scheme as the criterion, suggested that this coordination geometry is not that uncommon with ∼85 actinide compounds displaying such connectivity in some fashion, yet most of these occurrences (63) are molecular species, suggesting this connectivity is an underdeveloped mode for the architecture of higher dimensional structures. A requirement for the promotion of multidimensional compounds is of course additional functionality elsewhere on the linker molecule.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

The synthesis of novel thorium(IV) coordination polymers under hydrothermal conditions has been demonstrated utilizing a series of multifunctional ligands. We previously described a uranium(VI)-3,5-pyrazoledicarboxylate material, which contained a bidentate binding mode between the U(VI) metal centers to the linker through both the pyrazole ring along with a carboxylate group to form a five-membered ring (Scheme ). A search of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD; Version 5.28) using Scheme  as the criterion, suggested that this coordination geometry is not that uncommon with ~85 actinide compounds displaying such connectivity in some fashion, yet most of these occurrences (63) are molecular species, suggesting this connectivity is an underdeveloped mode for the architecture of higher dimensional structures. A requirement for the promotion of multidimensional compounds is of course additional functionality elsewhere on the linker molecule.

elements.content: Subsequently, a series of pyridinedicarboxylic acids were chosen (keeping the previously mentioned binding mode in consideration) during attempts to synthesize additional uranium coordination polymers. With the success of creating extended structures using this approach, we expanded our work toward thorium(IV) as the actinide metal center.
elements.clean_text: Subsequently, a series of pyridinedicarboxylic acids were chosen (keeping the previously mentioned binding mode in consideration) during attempts to synthesize additional uranium coordination polymers. With the success of creating extended structures using this approach, we expanded our work toward thorium(IV) as the actinide metal center.

elements.content: The synthesis of transition metal and lanthanide based materials (previously mentioned) utilizing pyridinedicarboxylic acids is evidence of the appeal of these ligands for producing homometallic along with heterometallic compounds due to the presence of the two distinct functional groups, yet a limited number of actinide-based coordination polymers have been reported. No thorium(IV) compounds have been previously reported; however, a uranium(VI)-2,3-pydc and -2,4-pydc have been illustrated by Cahill et al., while a second uranium(VI)-2,4-pydc was synthesized by Tong et al. all of which have a similar bidentate binding mode as illustrated in Scheme . It is perhaps more relevant, however, to discuss thorium and lanthanide containing compounds as this provides a more suitable comparison due to the similar coordination geometries associated with both Th(IV) and Ln(III). Min and Lee synthesized a Tb-2,4-pydc compound whereby the metal center is coordinated to three 2,4-pydc units through a single carboxylate oxygen atom, while a fourth organic linker is bound through both the pyridine ring and a carboxylate oxygen atom. Finally, one bound water molecule and an oxalate anion connecting the Tb metal centers completes the 8-coordinate local geometry. The coordination number and amount of bound organic linkers are lower than those observed in 2 possibly due to the presence of the oxalate anion. The bonding distances for the Tb/Th−O and Tb/Th−N along with the subsequent O−Tb/Th-N angle can be compared for these two compounds. The terbium compound has average distances of 2.345 and 2.639 Å (Tb−O and Tb−N) for an ensuing angle of 63.5°. The average Th−O and Th−N distances of 2.379 and 2.763 Å are both longer while the corresponding O−Th−N angle of 61.7° is more acute than those observed in the analogous terbium compound. Several Ln-2,5-pydc (including isostructural) compounds have been synthesized, all of which consist of a Ln metal center bound to two distinct organic units in a bidentate fashion through both the pyridine ring along with a carboxylate group. The average Ln−O and Ln−N bond lengths of 2.418 and 2.605 Å are shorter than the analogous ones seen in compound 3, 2.434 and 2.720 Å, respectively, while the O−Ln−N angle of 63.39° is wider than the O−Th−N angle of 60.74°. Of the four 2,5-pydc linkers bound to 3, only one is bound through a carboxylate oxygen atom, whereas the Ln-based compounds (previously mentioned) contain between two and four such linkages. Compound 3 also contains the only protonated carboxylic group within the series of structures presented herein. Each of the carboxylate groups (associated with 1−2, 4−5) is deprotonated and bound to at least one thorium metal center. In the instance where only one oxygen atom is coordinated to a tetravalent thorium, the remaining oxygen is doubly bound as determined via bond distances and charge balancing considerations.

elements.content: The coordination modes of pydc and pzdc in the structurally characterized coordination polymers 1−5 are summarized in Scheme (and ). Lanthanide(III) polyhedra (and Th(IV) due to similar spherical coordination), by comparison, have the potential to polymerize into higher ordered species such as 1D chains and 2D slabs via edge-sharing of the metal centers in order to satisfy their large coordination spheres. All of the compounds presented herein however contain monomeric building units.

elements.content: Within the pyridinedicarboxylic acid system, the position of the second carboxylate group appears to have an effect on the overall dimensionality along with the total number of bound linkers to the thorium(IV) metal centers. Compounds 1 and 2 are both overall 3D structures with the 9-coordinate thorium metal cations bound to five and six organic units, two in a bidentate fashion forming the 5-membered ring. When thorium is combined with 2,5-pydc, the Th(IV) metal centers are coordinated to four organic units, three of which are in a bidentate fashion through the pyridine ring and a carboxylate group, resulting in 1D chains. The observed decrease in overall dimensionality within the pyridinedicarboxylic acid system could be due to the increased instance of the bidentate binding mode seen in 2,5-pydc (three instances) as opposed to both 2,3-pydc and 2,4-pydc (2), leaving a lower number of accessible binding sites.

elements.content: Similar to the series of pyridinedicarboxylic acids are the organic linkers, 2,3-pyrazinedicarboxylic or 2,5-pyrazinedicarboxylic acid, used to synthesize compounds 4 and 5 which represent novel linkers for tethering actinide metal centers into extended dimensional structures. Zheng and Jin previously synthesized a La-2,5-pzdc 3D compound whereby the La3+ centers are bound to four linkers through a single carboxylate oxygen atom, while two pzdc units are bound in a bidentate fashion through the pyrazine ring and a carboxylate group and with the addition of one bound water molecule results in a 9-coordinate local geometry. Compound 4 is similarly 9-coordinate; however, the decrease in linkers bound through a single carboxylate oxygen atom (4 vs 2) is offset by an increase in bound water molecules (1 vs 3). A series of isostructural lanthanide-containing compounds (Ln = La, Pr, Nd, and Eu) has been synthesized with 2,3-pzdc as the organic linker by Jin et al. Compound 5 consists of one unique coordination mode for the organic linker, two metal centers bound in a tridentate fashion, while Jin et al. illustrated three separate coordination modes for 2,3-pzdc within each compound, tetradentate (three metal centers), hexadentate (four metal centers), and heptadentate (five metal centers).

Zheng and Jin previously synthesized a La-2,5-pzdc 3D compound whereby the La3+ centers are bound to four linkers through a single carboxylate oxygen atom, while two pzdc units are bound in a bidentate fashion through the pyrazine ring and a carboxylate group and with the addition of one bound water molecule results in a 9-coordinate local geometry. Compound 4 is similarly 9-coordinate; however, the decrease in linkers bound through a single carboxylate oxygen atom (4 vs 2) is offset by an increase in bound water molecules (1 vs 3). A series of isostructural lanthanide-containing compounds (Ln = La, Pr, Nd, and Eu) has been synthesized with 2,3-pzdc as the organic linker by Jin et al. Compound 5 consists of one unique coordination mode for the organic linker, two metal centers bound in a tridentate fashion, while Jin et al. illustrated three separate coordination modes for 2,3-pzdc within each compound, tetradentate (three metal centers), hexadentate (four metal centers), and heptadentate (five metal centers).

elements.content: Compounds 4 and 5 both contain the Th(IV) cations bound to the organic linker forming the five-membered ring, and the corresponding bond lengths and angles can be compared to the pydc system. The average Th−N bond lengths in 4 and 5 are longer (2.803 vs 2.727 Å), while the Th−O bond lengths (2.371 vs 2.407 Å) and the resulting angles (60.7 vs 61.1) are both smaller. Both of the compounds synthesized with pyrazinedicarboxylic acid have the thorium metal center bound to four linkers with two coordinated in a bidentate fashion as observed in 4 to form an overall 3D structure, while all four pzdc units are coordinated to the metal cation in a similar bidentate fashion in 5 to form 2D sheets. The decrease in dimensionality seen within the pyrazinedicarboxylic acid system could be due to sterics of the organic linkers through the position of the second carboxylate group. In 2,3-pzdc (5), each of the carboxylate groups are located on the same side of the pyrazine ring (between both of the nitrogen atoms within the ring) leaving the reverse side no open binding sites for the thorium metal centers to coordinate; however, in 2,5-pzdc (4) the carboxylate groups are separated on opposite sides around the pyrazine ring.

In 2,3-pzdc (5), each of the carboxylate groups are located on the same side of the pyrazine ring (between both of the nitrogen atoms within the ring) leaving the reverse side no open binding sites for the thorium metal centers to coordinate; however, in 2,5-pzdc (4) the carboxylate groups are separated on opposite sides around the pyrazine ring.

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 both crystallize in the chiral P212121 space group. This is indeed a less common space group and the origin of the chirality is not immediately clear. There may be a structural theme emerging, however, wherein Th centers containing five-membered rings (Scheme ) and additional monodentate carboxylate groups are present in chiral structures. This is also the case for Th(C5H2N2O4)2(H2O)2 as previously reported by our group. Further, a preliminary investigation of the second harmonic generation ability of 1 suggests a response approximately 200 times that of quartz.
elements.clean_text: Compounds 1 and 2 both crystallize in the chiral P212121 space group. This is indeed a less common space group and the origin of the chirality is not immediately clear. There may be a structural theme emerging, however, wherein Th centers containing five-membered rings (Scheme ) and additional monodentate carboxylate groups are present in chiral structures. This is also the case for Th(C5H2N2O4)2(H2O)2 as previously reported by our group. Further, a preliminary investigation of the second harmonic generation ability of 1 suggests a response approximately 200 times that of quartz.

elements.content: An interesting observation with respect to compound 5 can be made: when the reaction temperature was elevated to 120 °C (5 was synthesized at 70 °C), the starting organic (2,3-pyrazinedicarboxylic acid) was not observed in the final crystalline product. Rather, Th(C2O4)2(H2O)2·2H2O was observed. In this compound, the thorium metal centers are alternatively bridged via oxalate (C2O4 2−) linkages which were proposed to result from decarboxylation of 2,3-pyrazinedicarboxylic acid followed by subsequent coupling of CO2. During experimental investigations, the oxalate formation through decarboxylation of the starting organic appeared to be temperature dependent whereby a thorium-oxalate compound was observed at the higher temperatures of 120−150 °C.
elements.clean_text: An interesting observation with respect to compound 5 can be made: when the reaction temperature was elevated to 120 °C (5 was synthesized at 70 °C), the starting organic (2,3-pyrazinedicarboxylic acid) was not observed in the final crystalline product. Rather, Th(C2O4)2(H2O)2⋅2H2O was observed. In this compound, the thorium metal centers are alternatively bridged via oxalate (C2O4 2-) linkages which were proposed to result from decarboxylation of 2,3-pyrazinedicarboxylic acid followed by subsequent coupling of CO2. During experimental investigations, the oxalate formation through decarboxylation of the starting organic appeared to be temperature dependent whereby a thorium-oxalate compound was observed at the higher temperatures of 120-150 °C.

elements.content: Compounds 1−5 represent novel thorium(IV) coordination polymers synthesized under hydrothermal conditions while utilizing a series of pyridinedicarboxylic and pyrazinedicarboxylic acids as the organic linker. All of the Th(IV) metal centers are bound to the respective organic linker in two distinct ways: either through a single carboxylate oxygen atom or in a bidentate fashion through both the pyridine/pyrazine ring and a carboxylate oxygen atom. As the second carboxylate group is arranged at various positions around the pyridine ring within the pyridinedicarboxylic acid system (compounds 1−3), the extent of coordination through the five-membered ring varies from 2 to 3 and the coordination number of the metal center also increased from 9 to 10. A similar observation occurred in the pyazinedicarboxylic acid system (compounds 4−5). While both compounds are bound to four organic linkers, all four are coordinated to the thorium metal centers in a bidentate fashion in 4 when the carboxylate groups are positioned on opposite sides of the pyrazine ring (2,5-pzdc). This may be considered an optimal geometry for maximizing this type of coordination. Compound 5 is bound to two (of the 4) 2,3-pzdc units through a single carboxylate oxygen atoms. Finally, when the experimental conditions of 5 were elevated to 120 °C a previously synthesized Th-oxalate was observed whereby the oxalate linkages are the result of decarboxylation of the starting material, 2,5-pzdc. These materials represent an extension of our understanding of molecular species toward polymeric materials via incorporation of relevant structural motifs. Further harnessing of the coordination geometries described above is in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Compounds 1-5 represent novel thorium(IV) coordination polymers synthesized under hydrothermal conditions while utilizing a series of pyridinedicarboxylic and pyrazinedicarboxylic acids as the organic linker. All of the Th(IV) metal centers are bound to the respective organic linker in two distinct ways: either through a single carboxylate oxygen atom or in a bidentate fashion through both the pyridine/pyrazine ring and a carboxylate oxygen atom. As the second carboxylate group is arranged at various positions around the pyridine ring within the pyridinedicarboxylic acid system (compounds 1-3), the extent of coordination through the five-membered ring varies from 2 to 3 and the coordination number of the metal center also increased from 9 to 10. A similar observation occurred in the pyazinedicarboxylic acid system (compounds 4-5). While both compounds are bound to four organic linkers, all four are coordinated to the thorium metal centers in a bidentate fashion in 4 when the carboxylate groups are positioned on opposite sides of the pyrazine ring (2,5-pzdc). This may be considered an optimal geometry for maximizing this type of coordination. Compound 5 is bound to two (of the 4) 2,3-pzdc units through a single carboxylate oxygen atoms. Finally, when the experimental conditions of 5 were elevated to 120 °C a previously synthesized Th-oxalate was observed whereby the oxalate linkages are the result of decarboxylation of the starting material, 2,5-pzdc. These materials represent an extension of our understanding of molecular species toward polymeric materials via incorporation of relevant structural motifs. Further harnessing of the coordination geometries described above is in progress.
